greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Smallest positive integer that can be expressed as the sum of consecutive primes in exactly n ways.
comment: a(10)-a(12) found by Wilfred Whiteside in 2007. - _Giovanni Resta_, May 07 2020
reference: R. K. Guy, Unsolved Problems In Number Theory, C2.
Leo Moser, Notes on number theory. III. On the sum of consecutive primes, Canad. Math. Bull. 6 (1963), pp. 159-161.
link: Carlos Rivera, Puzzle 46. Primes expressible as sum of consecutive primes in K ways, The Prime Puzzles and Problems Connection.
example: 41 = 41 = 11+13+17 = 2+3+5+7+11+13, 41 is the smallest number expressible in 3 ways, so a(3)=41.
a(0) = 1 because 1 cannot be expressed as the sum of any set of consecutive primes,
a(1) = 2 because 2 is the first prime,
The runs of primes corresponding to a(10)-a(13), in the format first prime (run length), are:
mathematica: lmt = 500000000; p = Prime@ Range@ PrimePi@ lmt; t = Table[0, {lmt}]; Do[s = 0; j = i; While[s = s + p[[j]]; s <= lmt, t[[s]]++; j++], {i, Length@ p}]; Table[ Position[t, n, 1, 1], {n, 0, 0}] (* _Robert G. Wilson v_, Feb 21 2011 *)
results.author: _Jud McCranie_, May 25 2000
